text.div:
Generated Narrative: StructureDefinition IHE.MHD.SimplifiedPublish.DocumentReference

NameFlagsCard.TypeDescription & Constraints
DocumentReference 0..*DocumentReferenceA reference to a document
Slices for extension 0..*ExtensionExtension
Slice: Unordered, Open by value:url
extension:sourcePatientInfo S0..1Reference(Patient)Source Patient Information
URL: http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/documentreference-sourcepatient
modifierExtension 0..0Extension
Slices for identifier S1..1IdentifierBusiness identifiers for the document
Slice: Unordered, Open by value:use
identifier:uniqueId S1..1UniqueIdIdentifierBusiness identifiers for the document
use 1..1codeusual | official | temp | secondary | old (If known)
Required Pattern: usual
status 1..1codecurrent | superseded | entered-in-error
Required Pattern: current
docStatus 0..0registered | partial | preliminary | final | amended | corrected | appended | cancelled | entered-in-error | deprecated | unknown
type S0..1CodeableConceptKind of document (LOINC if possible)
category S0..1CodeableConceptCategorization of document
subject 1..1Reference(Patient)Who/what is the subject of the document
event
concept 1..1CodeableConceptReference to a concept (by class)
facilityType S0..1CodeableConceptKind of facility where patient was seen
practiceSetting S0..1CodeableConceptAdditional details about where the content was created (e.g. clinical specialty)
period S0..1PeriodTime of service that is being documented
date S0..1instantWhen this document reference was created
author S0..*Reference(Practitioner | PractitionerRole | Organization | Device | Patient | RelatedPerson | CareTeam)Who and/or what authored the document
attester 0..1BackboneElementAttests to accuracy of the document
party 1..1Reference(Patient | RelatedPerson | Practitioner | PractitionerRole | Organization)Who attested the document
relatesTo S0..*BackboneElementRelationships to other documents
securityLabel S0..*CodeableConceptDocument security-tags
content 1..1BackboneElementDocument referenced
attachment
contentType 1..1codeMime type of the content, with charset etc.
language S0..1codeHuman language of the content (BCP-47)
data 1..1base64BinaryThe document is contained in the .data element, base64 encoded
url 0..0Uri where the data can be found
creation S0..1dateTimeDate attachment was first created
profile S0..1BackboneElementContent profile rules for the document
Slices for value[x] 1..1CodingCode|uri|canonical
Slice: Unordered, Open by type:$this
value[x]:valueCoding 1..1CodingCode|uri|canonical

Documentation for this format

name: SimplifiedPublishDocumentReference
title: MHD DocumentReference for Simplified Publish
description:
A profile on the DocumentReference resource for MHD Simplified Publish constraints. 
- MHD is based on the [IHE Document Sharing](https://profiles.ihe.net/ITI/HIE-Whitepaper/index.html) model, 
- the [3:4.1 Abstract Metadata Model](https://profiles.ihe.net/ITI/TF/Volume3/ch-4.1.html#4.1), and 
- the use defined here is FHIR DocumentReference implementation of the 
- ebRIM implementation at [3:4.2.3.2 Document Entry](https://profiles.ihe.net/ITI/TF/Volume3/ch-4.2.html#4.2.3.2).
- with use-cases and constraints found in [3:4.3 Additional Document Sharing Requirements](https://profiles.ihe.net/ITI/TF/Volume3/ch-4.3.html#4.3)

Simplified Publish
- Similar to Minimal Metadata constraints
  - must be status current
  - must have a patient indicated
- uses attachment.data to carry the document, rather than attachment.url
  - so that the Simplified Publish is a simple POST of the DocumentReference
  - Document Recipient is expected to extract the .data, use .url

element.definition: A reference to a document of any kind for any purpose. While the term document implies a more narrow focus, for this resource this "document" encompasses *any* serialized object with a mime-type, it includes formal patient-centric documents (CDA), clinical notes, scanned paper, non-patient specific documents like policy text, as well as a photo, video, or audio recording acquired or used in healthcare.  The DocumentReference resource provides metadata about the document so that the document can be discovered and managed.  The actual content may be inline base64 encoded data or provided by direct reference.
element.comment: Usually, this is used for documents other than those defined by FHIR.

constraint.human: facilityType SHALL only be present if context is not an encounter
practiceSetting SHALL only be present if context is not present
If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT contain nested Resources
If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL be referred to from elsewhere in the resource or SHALL refer to the containing resource
constraint.expression: contained.where((('#'+id in (%resource.descendants().reference | %resource.descendants().ofType(canonical) | %resource.descendants().ofType(uri) | %resource.descendants().ofType(url))) or descendants().where(reference = '#').exists() or descendants().where(ofType(canonical) = '#').exists() or descendants().where(ofType(canonical) = '#').exists()).not()).trace('unmatched', id).empty()

constraint.human: If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a meta.versionId or a meta.lastUpdated
If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a security label

extension.valueMarkdown: When a resource has no narrative, only systems that fully understand the data can display the resource to a human safely. Including a human readable representation in the resource makes for a much more robust eco-system and cheaper handling of resources by intermediary systems. Some ecosystems restrict distribution of resources to only those systems that do fully understand the resources, and as a consequence implementers may believe that the narrative is superfluous. However experience shows that such eco-systems often open up to new participants over time.

constraint.human: A resource should have narrative for robust management

mapping.map: Entity, Role, or Act,Document[classCode="DOC" and moodCode="EVN"]

element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: Within the context of the FHIR RESTful interactions, the resource has an id except for cases like the create and conditional update. Otherwise, the use of the resouce id depends on the given use case.

element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
element.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of its narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies its meaning or interpretation

element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: IETF language tag for a human language

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comment: Contained resources do not have a narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, nor can they have their own independent transaction scope. This is allowed to be a Parameters resource if and only if it is referenced by a resource that provides context/meaning.
element.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags in their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels.

element.definition: An Extension

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition: The Patient Information as known when the document was published. May be a reference to a version specific, or contained.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition: An Extension

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the resource that contains them

element.definition: Other business identifiers associated with the document, including version independent identifiers.
element.comment: The structure and format of this identifier would be consistent with the specification corresponding to the format of the document. (e.g. for a DICOM standard document, a 64-character numeric UID; for an HL7 CDA format, the CDA Document Id root and extension).
element.requirements: Document identifiers usually assigned by the source of the document, or other business identifiers such as XDS DocumentEntry.uniqueId and DocumentEntry.entryUUID. These identifiers are specific to this instance of the document.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Other business identifiers associated with the document, including version independent identifiers.
element.comment: The structure and format of this identifier would be consistent with the specification corresponding to the format of the document. (e.g. for a DICOM standard document, a 64-character numeric UID; for an HL7 CDA format, the CDA Document Id root and extension).
element.requirements: Document identifiers usually assigned by the source of the document, or other business identifiers such as XDS DocumentEntry.uniqueId and DocumentEntry.entryUUID. These identifiers are specific to this instance of the document.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and managable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: usual | official | temp | secondary | old (If known)
element.definition: The purpose of this identifier.
element.comment: Applications can assume that an identifier is permanent unless it explicitly says that it is temporary.
element.requirements: Allows the appropriate identifier for a particular context of use to be selected from among a set of identifiers.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary id for a permanent one.

binding.description: Identifies the purpose for this identifier, if known .

element.definition: A coded type for the identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose.
element.comment: This element deals only with general categories of identifiers.  It SHOULD not be used for codes that correspond 1..1 with the Identifier.system. Some identifiers may fall into multiple categories due to common usage.   Where the system is known, a type is unnecessary because the type is always part of the system definition. However systems often need to handle identifiers where the system is not known. There is not a 1:1 relationship between type and system, since many different systems have the same type.
element.requirements: Allows users to make use of identifiers when the identifier system is not known.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: A coded type for an identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose.

element.short: The namespace for the identifier value
element.definition: Establishes the namespace for the value - that is, an absolute URL that describes a set values that are unique.
element.comment: Identifier.system is always case sensitive.
element.requirements: There are many sets  of identifiers.  To perform matching of two identifiers, we need to know what set we're dealing with. The system identifies a particular set of unique identifiers.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The portion of the identifier typically relevant to the user and which is unique within the context of the system.
element.comment: If the value is a full URI, then the system SHALL be urn:ietf:rfc:3986.  The value's primary purpose is computational mapping.  As a result, it may be normalized for comparison purposes (e.g. removing non-significant whitespace, dashes, etc.)  A value formatted for human display can be conveyed using the [http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/rendered-value](http://hl7.org/fhir/extensions/StructureDefinition-rendered-value.html)). Identifier.value is to be treated as case sensitive unless knowledge of the Identifier.system allows the processer to be confident that non-case-sensitive processing is safe.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: II.extension or II.root if system indicates OID or GUID (Or Role.id.extension or root)

element.short: Time period when id is/was valid for use
element.definition: Time period during which identifier is/was valid for use.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Organization that issued id (may be just text)
element.definition: Organization that issued/manages the identifier.
element.comment: The Identifier.assigner may omit the .reference element and only contain a .display element reflecting the name or other textual information about the assigning organization.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: II.assigningAuthorityName but note that this is an improper use by the definition of the field.  Also Role.scoper

element.short: An explicitly assigned identifer of a variation of the content in the DocumentReference
element.definition: An explicitly assigned identifer of a variation of the content in the DocumentReference.
element.comment: While each resource, including the DocumentReference itself, has its own version identifier, this is a formal identifier for the logical version of the DocumentReference as a whole. It would remain constant if the resources were moved to a new server, and all got new individual resource versions, for example.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Procedure that caused this media to be created
element.definition: A procedure that is fulfilled in whole or in part by the creation of this media.
element.requirements: Allows tracing of authorization for the event and tracking whether proposals/recommendations were acted upon.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The status of this document reference.
element.comment:
This is the status of the DocumentReference object, which might be independent from the docStatus element.

This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains the codes that mark the document or reference as not currently valid.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element is labelled as a modifier because it is a status element that contains status entered-in-error which means that the resource should not be treated as valid

binding.description: The status of the document reference.

mapping.map: interim: .completionCode="IN" & ./statusCode[isNormalDatatype()]="active";  final: .completionCode="AU" &&  ./statusCode[isNormalDatatype()]="complete" and not(./inboundRelationship[typeCode="SUBJ" and isNormalActRelationship()]/source[subsumesCode("ActClass#CACT") and moodCode="EVN" and domainMember("ReviseDocument", code) and isNormalAct()]);  amended: .completionCode="AU" &&  ./statusCode[isNormalDatatype()]="complete" and ./inboundRelationship[typeCode="SUBJ" and isNormalActRelationship()]/source[subsumesCode("ActClass#CACT") and moodCode="EVN" and domainMember("ReviseDocument", code) and isNormalAct() and statusCode="completed"];  withdrawn : .completionCode=NI &&  ./statusCode[isNormalDatatype()]="obsolete"

element.short: registered | partial | preliminary | final | amended | corrected | appended | cancelled | entered-in-error | deprecated | unknown
element.definition: The status of the underlying document.
element.comment: The document that is pointed to might be in various lifecycle states.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Imaging modality used. This may include both acquisition and non-acquisition modalities.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Type of acquired data in the instance.

element.definition: Specifies the particular kind of document referenced  (e.g. History and Physical, Discharge Summary, Progress Note). This usually equates to the purpose of making the document referenced.
element.comment: Key metadata element describing the document that describes he exact type of document. Helps humans to assess whether the document is of interest when viewing a list of documents.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map:
ClinicalDocument/code/@code 

The typeCode should be mapped from the ClinicalDocument/code element to a set of document type codes configured in the affinity domain. One suggested coding system to use for typeCode is LOINC, in which case the mapping step can be omitted.

element.definition: A categorization for the type of document referenced - helps for indexing and searching. This may be implied by or derived from the code specified in the DocumentReference.type.
element.comment: Key metadata element describing the the category or classification of the document. This is a broader perspective that groups similar documents based on how they would be used. This is a primary key used in searching.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: High-level kind of document at a macro level.

mapping.map: Derived from a mapping of /ClinicalDocument/code/@code to an Affinity Domain specified coded value to use and coding system. Affinity Domains are encouraged to use the appropriate value for Type of Service, based on the LOINC Type of Service (see Page 53 of the LOINC User's Manual). Must be consistent with /ClinicalDocument/code/@code

element.short: Who/what is the subject of the document
element.definition: Who or what the document is about. The document can be about a person, (patient or healthcare practitioner), a device (e.g. a machine) or even a group of subjects (such as a document about a herd of farm animals, or a set of patients that share a common exposure).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: PID-3 (No standard way to define a Practitioner or Group subject in HL7 V2 MDM message)

element.definition: Describes the clinical encounter or type of care that the document content is associated with.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: unique(highest(./outboundRelationship[typeCode="SUBJ" and isNormalActRelationship()], priorityNumber)/target[moodCode="EVN" and classCode=("ENC", "PCPR") and isNormalAct])

element.definition: This list of codes represents the main clinical acts, such as a colonoscopy or an appendectomy, being documented. In some cases, the event is inherent in the type Code, such as a "History and Physical Report" in which the procedure being documented is necessarily a "History and Physical" act.
element.comment: An event can further specialize the act inherent in the type, such as  where it is simply "Procedure Report" and the procedure was a "colonoscopy". If one or more event codes are included, they shall not conflict with the values inherent in the class or type elements as such a conflict would create an ambiguous situation.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: This list of codes represents the main clinical acts being documented.

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition: A reference to a concept - e.g. the information is identified by its general class to the degree of precision found in the terminology.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A reference to a resource the provides exact details about the information being referenced.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The anatomic structures included in the document.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Kind of facility where patient was seen
element.definition: The kind of facility where the patient was seen.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: usually from a mapping to a local ValueSet
usually a mapping to a local ValueSet. Must be consistent with /clinicalDocument/code

element.short: Additional details about where the content was created (e.g. clinical specialty)
element.definition: This property may convey specifics about the practice setting where the content was created, often reflecting the clinical specialty.
element.comment: This element should be based on a coarse classification system for the class of specialty practice. Recommend the use of the classification system for Practice Setting, such as that described by the Subject Matter Domain in LOINC.
element.requirements: This is an important piece of metadata that providers often rely upon to quickly sort and/or filter out to find specific content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Additional details about where the content was created (e.g. clinical specialty).

mapping.map: usually from a mapping to a local ValueSet
usually from a mapping to a local ValueSet

element.short: Time of service that is being documented
element.definition: The time period over which the service that is described by the document was provided.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: When this document reference was created
element.definition: When the document reference was created.
element.comment: Referencing/indexing time is used for tracking, organizing versions and searching.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Who and/or what authored the document
element.definition: Identifies who is responsible for adding the information to the document.
element.comment: Not necessarily who did the actual data entry (i.e. typist) or who was the source (informant).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: TXA-9 (No standard way to indicate a Device in HL7 V2 MDM message)

element.short: Attests to accuracy of the document
element.definition: A participant who has authenticated the accuracy of the document.
element.comment: Only list each attester once.
element.requirements: Identifies responsibility for the accuracy of the document content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored even if unrecognized
element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element and that modifies the understanding of the element in which it is contained and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and managable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](http://hl7.org/fhir/R5/extensibility.html#modifierExtension).

Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition: The type of attestation the authenticator offers.
element.requirements: Indicates the level of authority of the attestation.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The way in which a person authenticated a document.

element.definition: When the document was attested by the party.
element.requirements: Identifies when the information in the document was deemed accurate.  (Things may have changed since then.).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Who attested the document in the specified way.
element.requirements: Identifies who has taken on the responsibility for accuracy of the document content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: ./role[classCode="ASSIGNED" and isNormalRole]/player[determinerCode="INST" and classCode=("DEV", "PSN") and isNormalEntity()] or ./role[classCode="ASSIGNED" and isNormalRole and not(player)]/scoper[determinerCode="INST" and classCode="ORG" and isNormalEntity()]

element.definition: Identifies the organization or group who is responsible for ongoing maintenance of and access to the document.
element.comment: Identifies the logical organization (software system, vendor, or department) to go to find the current version, where to report issues, etc. This is different from the physical location (URL, disk drive, or server) of the document, which is the technical location of the document, which host may be delegated to the management of some other organization.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Relationships that this document has with other document references that already exist.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because documents that append to other documents are incomplete on their own.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the element that contains them

element.short: The relationship type with another document
element.definition: The type of relationship that this document has with anther document.
element.comment: If this document appends another document, then the document cannot be fully understood without also accessing the referenced document.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The type of relationship between the documents.

element.definition: The target document of this relationship.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Human-readable description of the source document.
element.comment: What the document is about,  a terse summary of the document.
element.requirements: Helps humans to assess whether the document is of interest.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A set of Security-Tag codes specifying the level of privacy/security of the Document found at DocumentReference.content.attachment.url. Note that DocumentReference.meta.security contains the security labels of the data elements in DocumentReference, while DocumentReference.securityLabel contains the security labels for the document the reference refers to. The distinction recognizes that the document may contain sensitive information, while the DocumentReference is metadata about the document and thus might not be as sensitive as the document. For example: a psychotherapy episode may contain highly sensitive information, while the metadata may simply indicate that some episode happened.
element.comment:
The confidentiality codes can carry multiple vocabulary items. HL7 has developed an understanding of security and privacy tags that might be desirable in a Document Sharing environment, called HL7 Healthcare Privacy and Security Classification System (HCS). The following specification is recommended but not mandated, as the vocabulary bindings are an administrative domain responsibility. The use of this method is up to the policy domain such as the XDS Affinity Domain or other Trust Domain where all parties including sender and recipients are trusted to appropriately tag and enforce.   

In the HL7 Healthcare Privacy and Security Classification (HCS) there are code systems specific to Confidentiality, Sensitivity, Integrity, and Handling Caveats. Some values would come from a local vocabulary as they are related to workflow roles and special projects.
element.requirements: Use of the Health Care Privacy/Security Classification (HCS) system of security-tag use is recommended.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Example Security Labels from the Healthcare Privacy and Security Classification System.

element.definition: The document and format referenced.
element.comment: content element shall not contain different versions of the same content. For version handling use multiple DocumentReference with .relatesTo.
element.requirements: Note that .relatesTo may also include references to other DocumentReference with a transforms relationship to represent the same document in multiple formats.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and managable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored even if unrecognized
element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element and that modifies the understanding of the element in which it is contained and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and managable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](http://hl7.org/fhir/R5/extensibility.html#modifierExtension).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the element that contains them

element.definition: The document or URL of the document along with critical metadata to prove content has integrity.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: DocumentEntry.mimeType, DocumentEntry.languageCode, DocumentEntry.URI, DocumentEntry.size, DocumentEntry.hash, DocumentEntry.title, DocumentEntry.creationTime

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and managable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Mime type of the content, with charset etc.
element.definition: Identifies the type of the data in the attachment and allows a method to be chosen to interpret or render the data. Includes mime type parameters such as charset where appropriate.
element.requirements: Processors of the data need to be able to know how to interpret the data.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: ED.2+ED.3/RP.2+RP.3. Note conversion may be needed if old style values are being used

element.definition: The human language of the content. The value can be any valid value according to BCP 47.
element.requirements: Users need to be able to choose between the languages in a set of attachments.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: IETF language tag for a human language.

element.short: The document is contained in the .data element, base64 encoded
element.definition: The actual data of the attachment - a sequence of bytes, base64 encoded.
element.comment: The base64-encoded data SHALL be expressed in the same character set as the base resource XML or JSON.
element.requirements: The data needs to able to be transmitted inline.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Uri where the data can be found
element.definition: A location where the data can be accessed.
element.comment: If both data and url are provided, the url SHALL point to the same content as the data contains. Urls may be relative references or may reference transient locations such as a wrapping envelope using cid: though this has ramifications for using signatures. Relative URLs are interpreted relative to the service url, like a resource reference, rather than relative to the resource itself. If a URL is provided, it SHALL resolve to actual data.
element.requirements: The data needs to be transmitted by reference.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: RP.1+RP.2 - if they refer to a URL (see v2.6)

element.short: Number of bytes of content (if url provided)
element.definition: The number of bytes of data that make up this attachment (before base64 encoding, if that is done).
element.comment: The number of bytes is redundant if the data is provided as a base64binary, but is useful if the data is provided as a url reference.
element.requirements: Representing the size allows applications to determine whether they should fetch the content automatically in advance, or refuse to fetch it at all.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The calculated hash of the data using SHA-1. Represented using base64.
element.comment: The hash is calculated on the data prior to base64 encoding, if the data is based64 encoded. The hash is not intended to support digital signatures. Where protection against malicious threats a digital signature should be considered, see [Provenance.signature](http://hl7.org/fhir/R5/provenance-definitions.html#Provenance.signature) for mechanism to protect a resource with a digital signature.
element.requirements: Included so that applications can verify that the contents of a location have not changed due to technical failures (e.g., storage rot, transport glitch, incorrect version).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Label to display in place of the data
element.definition: A label or set of text to display in place of the data.
element.comment: May sometimes be derived from the source filename.
element.requirements: Applications need a label to display to a human user in place of the actual data if the data cannot be rendered or perceived by the viewer.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The date that the attachment was first created.
element.requirements: This is often tracked as an integrity issue for use of the attachment.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Height of the image in pixels (photo/video)
element.definition: Height of the image in pixels (photo/video).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Width of the image in pixels (photo/video)
element.definition: Width of the image in pixels (photo/video).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The number of frames in a photo. This is used with a multi-page fax, or an imaging acquisition context that takes multiple slices in a single image, or an animated gif. If there is more than one frame, this SHALL have a value in order to alert interface software that a multi-frame capable rendering widget is required.
element.comment: if the number of frames is not supplied, the value may be unknown. Applications should not assume that there is only one frame unless it is explicitly stated.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The duration of the recording in seconds - for audio and video.
element.comment: The duration might differ from occurrencePeriod if recording was paused.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The number of pages when printed.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Content profile rules for the document
element.definition: An identifier of the document constraints, encoding, structure, and template that the document conforms to beyond the base format indicated in the mimeType.
element.comment:
Note that IHE often issues URNs for formatCode codes, not all documents can be identified by a URI.

For FHIR content, .profile should indicate the structureDefinition profile canonical URI(s) that the content complies with.
